metadata.Title: CVE-2016-1923 on Ubuntu 16.04 ESM (xenial) - low.
metadata.Description:
Heap-based buffer overflow in the opj_j2k_update_image_data function in OpenJpeg 2016.1.18 allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (out-of-bounds read and application crash) via a crafted JPEG 2000 image.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2016-1923` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libopenjp2-7 - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjp2-tools - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjp3d-tools - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjp3d7 - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjpip-dec-server - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjpip-server - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjpip-viewer - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
libopenjpip7 - 2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1
No subscription required

notes.Note: ccdm94> in issue 704, which references this CVE, there is mention of commit d26481f24bd (mayeut/openjpeg), which seems to be aimed at fixing this issue. This commit, however, was not included by upstream. The code has changed to something that is similar to what is proposed in the previously mentioned non-merged commit, and the commit that did this was ad593c9e062. This seems to be the same fix as the one for CVE-2016-3182. Considering that this is the fix for the issue, even if package openjpeg (versions 1.x) is affected (PoC does not reproduce), the only likely upstream patch does not apply as the function being patched does not exist in versions 1.x. No other possible patch has been explicitly provided by upstream.

criterions.comment: openjpeg2 package in xenial was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '2.1.2-1.1+deb9u2build0.1').
